Jam10o 23-Nov-21 02:53 PM
cryptocurrency's kinda doing itself a disservice by being difficult to approach
as someone who is deeply ingrained in one of the PoS blockchain ecosystems outlined in the paper and sheet you linked above - I promise you that we're trying to do everything we can to present our solutions to the world and to address the concern folks have with the cryptocurrency space, but the fact of the matter is that the people who have the money (and therefore decide what's at the top of the market cap charts and what's in the news) don't necessarily care, and the people who care (ie, folks who are building PoS chains, or experimenting with more decentralized economic distributions, or actively building DAOs and orgs to address climate and sustainability goals) didn't have much money until quite recently. But that's changing, the question is just if it changes fast enough.

Geenz | Graphics Programmer 24-Nov-21 01:53 PM
There's a ton of concerns around "up and switching" chains, especially given the delays around ETH2.0's merge are getting shorter and shorter, and we also have people with existing wallets outside of Neos that we should ensure don't get left behind somehow. It's also worth noting that we are still quite a small team at present, so iteration cycles must be used sparingly which further complicates this. I don't have like a concrete risk analysis here, and really the best I can say here is we're generally in favor of PoS despite NCR existing on a PoW chain. At the time that NCR was initially minted, PoS chains weren't super common, which meant we kind of had to go with what would likely get us the most exposure to ensure sustainable funding on that front which has resulted in the present situation we find ourselves in on Ethereum.
SAFollis 24-Nov-21 01:53 PM

PoW at least you have to actually use the money to sustain and increase how much you make, proof of stake that's basically not a thing (edited)
but any pow coin with asics, and even gpus are pretty crappy, and even some cpu mineable coins aren't set up as good as they could be for energy efficiency

There's a ton of concerns around "up and switching" chains, especially given the delays around ETH2.0's merge are getting shorter and shorter, and we also have people with existing wallets outside of Neos that we should ensure don't get left behind somehow. It's also worth noting that we are still quite a small team at present, so iteration cycles must be used sparingly which further complicates this. I don't have like a concrete risk analysis here, and really the best I can say here is we're generally in favor of PoS despite NCR existing on a PoW chain. At the time that NCR was initially minted, PoS chains weren't super common, which meant we kind of had to go with what would likely get us the most exposure to ensure sustainable funding on that front which has resulted in the present situation we find ourselves in on Ethereum.

Geenz | Graphics Programmer 24-Nov-21 02:08 PM

Geenz | Graphics Programmer
It's definitely going to be interesting to see how it evolves with different individuals and pools acting as validators. @Jam10o you seem to have a good deal of exposure around PoS- what have you seen happen?
Jam10o 24-Nov-21 02:11 PM
you never get to a perfectly decentralized distribution, obviously, and any system that gets set up ends up gamed to the advantage of the larger players. As with most things, the only thing you can do is watch what happens and fix problems as they come - for example on Kusama we've gradually increased to 1000 validators (and their pools of nominators) - the idea used to be that the bigger that number, the more decentralized things are, but a recent jump above 1000 disproved that theory, and now there's a community vote ongoing to cut everything down back to 850.
Geenz | Graphics Programmer 24-Nov-21 02:12 PM
Oh- huh. That's actually kinda interesting.
Jam10o 24-Nov-21 02:12 PM
the problem ends up being - the more space there is, the lower the barrier to entry gets (which is good), but if it gets too low, it's low enough that the bigger players can split themselves into smaller pieces and get a larger overall share of the pie
which wouldn't be a big deal, if it wasn't the case that the more pie you get, the faster you can grow (your capital, infrastructure, etc.)

Geenz | Graphics Programmer 26-Nov-21 05:57 PM
If you're presently pushing to have NFTs implemented in the immediate future, I'm sorry to say that it simply isn't happening. We have a very large pile of work that precedes this. However there has been some discussion in the general public around a variety of schemes involving NFTs that, although difficult to verify, are certainly worth consideration. I won't point out a specific example simply out of not wanting to portray my own views as indicative of Neos', but as I mentioned some of these issues are not insurmountable - it just requires careful thought and consideration in terms of how we integrate NFTs from different networks into Neos, and how we enable individuals to create NFTs from Neos. This is a bit longer term than "add NFTs in <x> period of time lets gooooooo" - and we haven't really had much time to fully flesh out those discussions. Afterall, time is our most valuable resource, and we already have quite the backlog of work we must get through before this makes sense.
Note that I'm not saying no, I'm saying not right now.
littleredbell
there is a base layer and the layers on top The base layer remains unaltered (it could be just an id, no need to be a base graphic)

I won't point out a specific example simply out of not wanting to portray my own views as indicative of Neos', but as I mentioned some of these issues are not insurmountable - it just requires careful thought and consideration in terms of how we integrate NFTs from different networks into Neos, and how we enable individuals to create NFTs from Neos. This is a bit longer term than "add NFTs in <x> period of time lets gooooooo" - and we haven't really had much time to fully flesh out those discussions. Afterall, time is our most valuable resource, and we already have quite the backlog of work we must get through before this makes sense.
VoidPaw 26-Nov-21 05:58 PM
I'm just trying to get clarity on what NFT bulls want to see for NFT integration. Because I'm still skeptical of the value proposition over current systems.
Geenz | Graphics Programmer

Jam10o 27-Nov-21 08:36 AM
lots of folks think NFTs are DRM but that's not entirely true - NFTs are generally publicly viewable, access to the content is not gated by ownership, and if you wanted to have that feature, you'd have to build a DRM solution on top of your NFT platform (such platforms exist but are wildly unpopular, because if folks can't see what they will be purchasing, they don't care about purchasing it) - it's largely a meme but the whole "right click, save as, now I own it" idea is largely because people believe NFTs to be related to DRM in some way when they are completely orthogonal concepts. NFTs are about verifiable providence/chain of ownership and even then, there's no protection against someone minting someone else's work as an NFT and selling it, other than good old fashioned moderation on the platform side, and using a legal system. I'd argue that the only legitimate investment thesis/use case for NFTs is for ownership of assets that are natively digital, provide access to something, represent membership of a group, or have an explicit paper/legal tie to real world assets.

0xD123 16-Dec-21 04:51 AM
charles hoskinson from cardano has talked about addressing this re-centralization problem.. i can't remember what he proposes... and i wouldn't own cardano only because of his weaksauce explanation.. but many have theorized on this eventual recentralization problem
fundamentally though... this is the tug of war between POS/Fiat vs. POW/gold-backed system. POW > POS because of the wealth centralization issues... and in the case of BTC, BTC > Gold because you can demand final settlement in the next block for a nominal transaction fee. for this reason, it is the ultimate final settlement-layer between central banks or governments or large institutions...
gold has the issue of infinite rehypothecation... precisely because final settlement is difficult.

Geenz | Graphics Programmer 16-Dec-21 05:26 AM
I guess my point of confusion over PoW vs. PoS is that I feel they ultimately have the same baseline problem: whoever has the most money has the highest chances of success at tipping the scale at this point - especially with these large mining operations you see popping up here and there. The biggest difference to me at the most fundamental level is with PoS I'm not purchasing a depreciating asset that's only purpose is to consume energy and provide proof that it has consumed this energy hence being proof of doing some amount of work, that I must then sell later to try and recoup that cost of doing business. I suppose the argument can be made that with PoW the penalties are far more severe than with PoS given the amount of energy expended, and the fact that I have a depreciating asset on my hands. If a miner tries to cheat, than they basically spent a ton money on hardware that makes them less and less money the more unscrupulous this miner is. PoS, at least in what I've read about ETH2.0's implementation so far, appears to have a sliding scale of penalties that eats into your staked ETH though, with a series of nodes that can act in different roles to ensure a more secure outcome. I haven't really fully explored all of the nuances with ETH's PoS implementation though - it seems they want to have penalties roughly in the ballpark.

The biggest difference to me at the most fundamental level is with PoS I'm not purchasing a depreciating asset that's only purpose is to consume energy and provide proof that it has consumed this energy hence being proof of doing some amount of work, that I must then sell later to try and recoup that cost of doing business. I suppose the argument can be made that with PoW the penalties are far more severe than with PoS given the amount of energy expended, and the fact that I have a depreciating asset on my hands. If a miner tries to cheat, than they basically spent a ton money on hardware that makes them less and less money the more unscrupulous this miner is. PoS, at least in what I've read about ETH2.0's implementation so far, appears to have a sliding scale of penalties that eats into your staked ETH though, with a series of nodes that can act in different roles to ensure a more secure outcome. I haven't really fully explored all of the nuances with ETH's PoS implementation though - it seems they want to have penalties roughly in the ballpark.
0xD123 16-Dec-21 05:30 AM
Mining decentralization is a key metric the BTC core devs or other project devs (including presumably ETH) look at... In fact, in 2016/2017 BTC core devs exposed mallicious behaviour by veritically integrated mining consortium bitmain.. this led to the fork wars of 2017.... (which is also well documented in a book now in case you are interested).... Since the fork wars, no miners have been able to gain even a dominant position on BTC... it's maintained decentralized mining... and if miners were to gain a 51% attack position, two things would happen.. the price would drop.. and the core devs could simply do a code change to invalidate all the miners by banning ASICS and reverting back to GPU or whatever.
SAFollis 16-Dec-21 05:31 AM
The simple way to calculate the number of Transactions Per Second (TPS) Bitcoin can handle is to divide the block size limit by the expected average size of transactions, divided by the average number of seconds between blocks (600). For example, if you assume average transactions are 250 bytes, 6.6 TPS = 1,000,000 / 250 / 600

Jam10o 16-Dec-21 05:00 PM
yep, among all modern PoS protocols it is the case that stakers' voting power only increases in relation to non-stakers, and since nomination/delegation of stake is generally a component of all of them, it is generally very easy to participate in staking even if you aren't actually validating, yourself the problem most PoS protocols are facing nowadays is actually validators who earn additional value outside of the real protocol from their staked tokens, ie, exchanges or other custodians - they can basically out compete other validators with their higher margins and accumulate more than others.

Geenz | Graphics Programmer 18-Dec-21 01:22 AM
This kinda circles back to the whole discussion around NFTs basically just being a glorified receipt of a transaction occurring. That's not a bad thing mind - just a different narrative on a fundamental level from: NFTs establish digital ownership. I'd argue that it's not as black and white as digital ownership. It's you have a receipt saying you have licensed a copy of, purchased the rights to, or otherwise have conducted some kind of transaction around some kind of digital good or service.
That also gets noted on a public blockchain based ledger.
It's also completely decoupled from the issue of storage and distribution. NFTs don't handle that side of things - you can have a "pointer" to where the asset, in theory, could be retrieved. But that breaks down if whoever is hosting this asset chooses to no longer host said asset. But then, I don't think anyone is really saying NFTs are a solution to the storage problem - nor should they.

Crypto mining is a great use of natural renewable energy sources such as geothermal and also utilize excess power that otherwise goes to waste. With crypto staking there's little economic incentive for a staker to rely on renewable/wasted power since no individual staker uses much energy. 0xD123 26-Dec-21 10:11 PM
crypto is a bearer asset. You need to compare it to other bearer assets, not with funds in a bank. If someone steals your cash at home then it's gone. If someone fraudulently gains access to your safety deposit box then the contents are gone... There probably will never be good insurance programs for bearer assets that you don't pay for -- usually in advance through fees or high interest rates. For example, most home insurance policies have limits on bearer assets due to risks... As for credit card fraud, or fraud from a bank account, after a certain period of elapsed time there is nothing a bank would do to recoup the funds and you would probably be out the money. within certain time periods banks or credit card companies would charge-back funds -- so that they are not really insuring the amount, but rather attempting to recouping it. If they failed to recoup it, they would probably be insured to a point but would probably be underwriting their own book (based on the profitability of their fee structure in the first place)...
and, if you don't see the value in a bearer asset that is free from government inflation, perhaps it's because you live in a country where there is a lot of privilege. That's pretty good for you. As for the rest of the world, they might not see it the same way.

Yea, so my question was, does proof of stake make massive, energy-draining rigs like that pointless? If so then that should help the GPU scarcity and significantly lower the environment impact of crypto
VoidPaw 31-Dec-21 01:28 PM
yes. proof of stake basically simulates mining by using a verified random function. So instead of massive mining farms like that one, we just need a network of low power servers called "validators" that serve as databases.
Here's a video that explains pure proof of stake and how it solves the blockchain trilemma. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gACVKaNqxPs

VoidPaw 31-Dec-21 01:48 PM
the guarantee is in the collateral. it's not a useful system but it is a system that works. Effectively in order to borrow bitcoin, you need to put up 100% collateral in another currency. The reason you'd borrow bitcoin is so that you can sell it and bet that the price of bitcoin will go down before you have to pay back the loan. (edited)
if the price of bitcoin goes up, your collateral gets liquidated.

0xD123 04-Jan-22 02:53 PM
30 seconds of googling yields this... https://climatestate.com/2018/01/15/energy-consumption-bitcoin-vs-banking-system/ https://bitcoinmagazine.com/business/not-science-digiconomist-bitcoin https://scienceforsustainability.org/wiki/Energy_consumption_of_electronics https://techcrunch.com/2021/03/21/the-debate-about-cryptocurrency-and-energy-consumption/ The first thing about being an 'economist' is the analysis of trade-offs -- specifically -- what is the opportunity cost of the alternatives. Digiconomist seems to only focus on the environmental concerns of Bitcoin and Ethereum but as far as I can tell -- fails to consider the alternative cost of the current legacy system. Just do these basic thought exercises yourself: How much capital today is invested in condos in Vancouver, London, Shanghai, Hong Kong, New York etc.. that wouldn't have been built if the monetary system incentivized savings with real interest rates. What is the greenhouse gas emissions and environmental cost of building these condos? How much concrete, rebar was produced and what emissions were required to produce them? How much greenhouse gas is embedded in running hundreds of thousands of ATMs, cash registers, visa terminals, armored cars, finance/banking towers? As for NFTs, how much greenhouse gas emission is embedded in the copywrite industry? How many lawyers, executives, accountants, notaries, judges, sheriffs, jurors, and bailiffs with their respective offices and facilities are directly or indirectly employed in this massive industry? If you haven't asked yourself these fundamental questions, you simply have not incorporated the meat-hook reality of central banking, cefi, and the legacy systems we currently are forced to deal with in your mental model. Or perhaps you are being intellectually dishonest like Digiconomist -- who I can't imagine has not thought of this. It seems they have done well providing click-bait to people in search of confirmation bias.
We Need To Talk About The NOT Science Behind Digiconomist
The lack of factual information utilized in reports by the publication is alarming and misleading.

David Riggs

Energy consumption has become the latest flashpoint for cryptocurrency. Jam10o 04-Jan-22 03:43 PM
consensus engineers consider PoW to be a temporary sidetrack in the field of distributed computing, though? - there are problems it solves (permissionless block producer selection), but there are better ways to solve them (propose block producers in a separate process to the one used to produce blocks), and it's generally considered counterproductive in terms of the properties of the distributed systems it creates (you don't have deterministic finality, and have basically 0 partition tolerance) (edited)

https://arxiv.org/abs/2108.10984
Crypto Wash Trading
We introduce systematic tests exploiting robust statistical and behavioral patterns in trading to detect fake transactions on 29 cryptocurrency exchanges. Regulated exchanges feature patterns...
"We introduce systematic tests exploiting robust statistical and behavioral patterns in trading to detect fake transactions on 29 cryptocurrency exchanges...We quantify the wash trading on each unregulated exchange, which averaged over 70% of the reported volume."
"A wash trade is a form of market manipulation in which an investor simultaneously sells and buys the same financial instruments to create misleading, artificial activity in the marketplace. First, an investor will place a sell order, then place a buy order to buy from themself, or vice versa." I knew it was a big issue with NFTs but apparently it's used to artificially inflate cryptocurrencies as well
70% is high

500M Avira Antivirus Users Introduced to Cryptomining
Many readers were surprised to learn recently that the popular Norton 360 antivirus suite now ships with a program which lets customers make money mining virtual currency. But Norton 360 isn't alone in this dubious endeavor: Avira antivirus -- which…

Even with compatible hardware, mining cryptocurrencies on your own can be less rewarding.
